title: nf-core/genomeskim pipeline parameters
description: QC and filtering of genome skims, followed by organelle assembly and/or genome analysis

input_output_options.title: Input/output options
input_output_options.description: Define where the pipeline should find input data and save output data.

input.description: Path to comma-separated file containing information about the samples in the experiment.
input.help_text: You will need to create a design file with information about the samples in your experiment before running the pipeline. Use this parameter to specify its location. It has to be a comma-separated file with 3 columns, and a header row. See [usage docs](https://nf-co.re/genomeskim/usage#samplesheet-input).

outdir.description: The output directory where the results will be saved. You have to use absolute paths to storage on Cloud infrastructure.

email.help_text: Set this parameter to your e-mail address to get a summary e-mail with details of the run sent to you when the workflow exits. If set in your user config file (`~/.nextflow/config`) then you don't need to specify this on the command line for every run.

multiqc_title.description: MultiQC report title. Printed as page header, used for filename if not otherwise specified.

adapter_removal_and_filtering.title: Adapter removal and filtering
adapter_removal_and_filtering.description: Parameters for fastp adapter removal and quality/length filtering

fastp_adapter_fasta.description: Path to fasta file containing adapters to remove
fastp_adapter_fasta.help_text: Fastp will auto-detect most common adapters, but to supply extra adapters to remove, supply them in a fasta file. Passed to `fastp --adapter_fasta`, see https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp#adapters

fastp_quality_filter_pclim.description: The percentage of bases that may be unqualified to retain a read
fastp_quality_filter_pclim.help_text:
Passed through to `fastp --unqualified_percent_limit`, see https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp#quality-filter

By default, no quality filtering is done, as recommended for getorganelle inputs, see https://github.com/Kinggerm/GetOrganelle#starting-from-reads. Decrease this value to perform quality filtering.

fastp_quality_filter_phred.description: The minimum phred score to qualify a base
fastp_quality_filter_phred.help_text:
Passed through to `fastp --unqualified_percent_limit`, see https://github.com/OpenGene/fastp#quality-filter

Note that this parameter has no effect if --fastp_quality_filter_pclim is set to 100, the default. Thus by default, no quality filtering is done, as recommended for getorganelle inputs, see https://github.com/Kinggerm/GetOrganelle#starting-from-reads.

fastp_length_filter_min.description: Minimum read length to be retained

adapter_removal_and_filtering.help_text: Parameters for removing trimming adapter sequences, quality filtering and length filtering.

custom_reference_options.title: Custom reference options
custom_reference_options.description: Options for supplying custom references to organelle assembly

organellerefs.description: Path to a fasta or genbank format file containing reference organelle sequences
organellerefs.help_text: Genbank-format flat file is recommended, in which case both the organelle and gene sequences will be used for GetOrganelle.

gofetch_taxon.description: Taxon or taxid of rank to search for, e.g. "3702" or "Arabidopsis". Required to use GoFetch

gofetch_target.description: Sequence type to retrieve. Required to use GoFetch

gofetch_minn.description: Minimum number of target sequences to download - fewer sequences will speed up runtime

gofetch_maxn.description: Maximum number of sequences to download - more sequences may increase assembly quality

gofetch_entrezemail.description: Email address for Entrez API queries, required to use GoFetch
gofetch_entrezemail.help_text: This should be an email address that you have registered with NCBI

gofetch_entrezapikey.description: API key for Entrez API queries, optional but may speed up runtime
gofetch_entrezapikey.help_text: See https://support.nlm.nih.gov/knowledgebase/article/KA-05317/en-us for how to get an API key

custom_reference_options.help_text:
The pipeline supports three ways for supplying references. If no custom references are supplied, the pipeline uses the default GetOrganelle references based on the genometype supplied to --getorganelle_genometype. Additional or alternative references can be used by supplying a file of referencese to --organellerefs and/or by using the go_fetch.py script to retrieve reference sequences from NCBI for a given taxon. Supplying a value to --gofetch_taxon will switch on using GoFetch; for more information see https://github.com/o-william-white/go_fetch.
To select which references to actually use for GetOrganelle and how, see --getorganelle_ref_action.

getorganelle_genometype.help_text:
Passed through to `get_organelle_from_reads.py -F`. Must be one or more (comma-separated list) of:
embplant_pt
other_pt
embplant_mt
embplant_nr
animal_mt
fungus_mt
fungus_nr
anonym
See https://github.com/Kinggerm/GetOrganelle/wiki/Usage#get_organelle_from_readspy
getorganelle_genometype.description: Target organelle genome type, in GetOrganelle format

getorganelle_wordsize.description: The word size for GetOrganelle, auto-estimated by GetOrganelle if not supplied

getorganelle_kmers.description: Kmer(s) to use for assembly with SPAdes within GetOrganelle
getorganelle_kmers.help_text: One or several kmers should be supplied, separated by commas. Multiple kmers are recommended, see https://github.com/Kinggerm/GetOrganelle?tab=readme-ov-file#starting-from-reads for more information.

getorganelle_maxreads.description: Maximum number of reads to use from inputs, no limit if not supplied

getorganelle_ref_action.description: Should the GetOrganelle default reference databases be used, and if so how.
getorganelle_ref_action.help_text:
If no custom references are specified (taxon for retrieval from GoFetch and/or reference(s) sequence files to --organellerefs), by default the pipeline will use the default GetOrganelle seed and label sequences.
If any custom references are supplied, seed and label sequences will instead derive from the custom references. To fine-tune which sequences will be used as GetOrganelle seed and label in this case, use the following:
`add_seeds`: combine the default GetOrganelle seeds with those derived from custom references
`add_labels`: combine the default GetOrganelle labels with those derived from custom references
`add_both`: combine both default Getorganelle seeds with custom reference seeds and default GetOrganelle labels with custom reference labels
`only_seeds`: ignore the custom reference seeds and use only the default GetOrganelle seeds
`only_labels`: ignore the custom reference genes and use only the default GetOrganelle labels
`only_both: ignore the custom references entirely and use only the defaulte GetOrganelle seeds and labels

getorganelle_reducereads.help_text: Default inf: no reducing of reads for coverage
getorganelle_reducereads.description: Maximum number of reads according to coverage. Default: no limit

validation_options.title: Validation options
validation_options.description: Options for performing automated checks on GetOrganelle outputs

blastdbpath.description: Path to a directory containing a BLAST-format reference database
blastdbpath.help_text: The reference database must have been created using the -taxid_map to map NCBI taxids to entries. Local copies of nt, nr or refseq will work, but may be quite slow, better to use a curated database comprising your taxon of interest AND a selection of potential contaminants

annotation_options.title: Annotation options
annotation_options.description: Options for performing annotation on mitochondrial contigs

skip_annotation.description: Skip annotation process - recommended for non-mitochondrial data

mitos_plots.description: Create annotation plots - will be slower

mitos_refdbid.description: Specify one of six MITOS2 reference databases

genome_statistics_options.title: Genome Statistics options
genome_statistics_options.description: Options for computing genome summaries on the non-organellar reads

genomestats_kmer.help_text: Passed to the -m option in Jellyfish2 and the -k option in Genomescope2

generic_options.title: Generic options
generic_options.description: Less common options for the pipeline, typically set in a config file.
generic_options.help_text:
These options are common to all nf-core pipelines and allow you to customise some of the core preferences for how the pipeline runs.

Typically these options would be set in a Nextflow config file loaded for all pipeline runs, such as `~/.nextflow/config`.

publish_dir_mode.description: Method used to save pipeline results to output directory.
publish_dir_mode.help_text: The Nextflow `publishDir` option specifies which intermediate files should be saved to the output directory. This option tells the pipeline what method should be used to move these files. See [Nextflow docs](https://www.nextflow.io/docs/latest/process.html#publishdir) for details.

email_on_fail.description: Email address for completion summary, only when pipeline fails.
email_on_fail.help_text: An email address to send a summary email to when the pipeline is completed - ONLY sent if the pipeline does not exit successfully.

plaintext_email.description: Send plain-text email instead of HTML.

max_multiqc_email_size.description: File size limit when attaching MultiQC reports to summary emails.

monochrome_logs.description: Do not use coloured log outputs.

hook_url.description: Incoming hook URL for messaging service
hook_url.help_text: Incoming hook URL for messaging service. Currently, only MS Teams is supported.

multiqc_config.description: Custom config file to supply to MultiQC.

multiqc_logo.description: Custom logo file to supply to MultiQC. File name must also be set in the MultiQC config file

multiqc_methods_description.description: Custom MultiQC yaml file containing HTML including a methods description.

validate_params.description: Boolean whether to validate parameters against the schema at runtime

max_job_request_options.title: Max job request options
max_job_request_options.description: Set the top limit for requested resources for any single job.
max_job_request_options.help_text:
If you are running on a smaller system, a pipeline step requesting more resources than are available may cause the Nextflow to stop the run with an error. These options allow you to cap the maximum resources requested by any single job so that the pipeline will run on your system.

Note that you can not _increase_ the resources requested by any job using these options. For that you will need your own configuration file. See [the nf-core website](https://nf-co.re/usage/configuration) for details.

max_cpus.description: Maximum number of CPUs that can be requested for any single job.
max_cpus.help_text: Use to set an upper-limit for the CPU requirement for each process. Should be an integer e.g. `--max_cpus 1`

max_memory.description: Maximum amount of memory that can be requested for any single job.
max_memory.help_text: Use to set an upper-limit for the memory requirement for each process. Should be a string in the format integer-unit e.g. `--max_memory '8.GB'`

max_time.description: Maximum amount of time that can be requested for any single job.
max_time.help_text: Use to set an upper-limit for the time requirement for each process. Should be a string in the format integer-unit e.g. `--max_time '2.h'`

institutional_config_options.title: Institutional config options
institutional_config_options.description: Parameters used to describe centralised config profiles. These should not be edited.
institutional_config_options.help_text: The centralised nf-core configuration profiles use a handful of pipeline parameters to describe themselves. This information is then printed to the Nextflow log when you run a pipeline. You should not need to change these values when you run a pipeline.

custom_config_version.description: Git commit id for Institutional configs.

custom_config_base.help_text: If you're running offline, Nextflow will not be able to fetch the institutional config files from the internet. If you don't need them, then this is not a problem. If you do need them, you should download the files from the repo and tell Nextflow where to find them with this parameter.
